LayoutNode.SRC: Michael Bernstein  ·  Stanford HCI

LayoutNode.Content: I combine crowds with computation, designing sociotechnical supercolliders of human interest and knowledge. My group's research in human-computer interaction develops crowdsourcing systems, designs social computing environments, and mines crowd data for interactive applications.
LayoutNode.SRC: I combine crowds with computation, designing sociotechnical supercolliders of human interest and knowledge. My group's research in human-computer interaction develops crowdsourcing systems, designs social computing environments, and mines crowd data for interactive applications.

LayoutNode.Content: Michael Bernstein is an Assistant Professor of Computer Science at Stanford University, where he directs the Human-Computer Interaction group and is a Robert N. Noyce Family Faculty Scholar. His research in human-computer interaction focuses on the design of crowdsourcing and social computing systems. This work has received Best Paper awards and nominations at premier venues in human-computer interaction and social computing (ACM UIST, ACM CHI, ACM CSCW, AAAI ISWSM). Michael has been recognized with the NSF CAREER award, as well as the George M. Sprowls Award for best doctoral thesis in Computer Science at MIT. He holds Ph.D. and masters degrees in Computer Science from MIT, and a B.S. in Symbolic Systems from Stanford University.
LayoutNode.SRC: Michael Bernstein is an Assistant Professor of Computer Science at Stanford University, where he directs the Human-Computer Interaction group and is a Robert N. Noyce Family Faculty Scholar. His research in human-computer interaction focuses on the design of crowdsourcing and social computing systems. This work has received Best Paper awards and nominations at premier venues in human-computer interaction and social computing (ACM UIST, ACM CHI, ACM CSCW, AAAI ISWSM). Michael has been recognized with the NSF CAREER award, as well as the George M. Sprowls Award for best doctoral thesis in Computer Science at MIT. He holds Ph.D. and masters degrees in Computer Science from MIT, and a B.S. in Symbolic Systems from Stanford University.
